column2: The entire group of individuals or instances about which we want to learn.
A subset of a population examined to learn about the entire group.
A study that asks questions of a sample drawn from a population to learn about the whole population.
A systematic failure of a sampling method that results in over- or underestimating population parameters.
A method that ensures each individual has an equal chance of selection, reducing bias.
The number of individuals included in a sample, influencing how well it represents the population.
A sample that consists of the entire population.
A numerically valued attribute of a model for a population, often estimated from sampled data.
Values calculated from sampled data that estimate population parameters.
A sample accurately reflecting the corresponding population parameters.
A sample where each set of elements has an equal chance of being selected.
A list of individuals from whom the sample is drawn.
The natural tendency for randomly drawn samples to differ from one another.
A sampling design where the population is divided into subpopulations, and samples are drawn from each.
A sampling design where entire groups are chosen at random, with each group being representative of the population.
A sampling design that combines several methods, such as stratifying the population and then selecting clusters within each stratum.
A sample drawn by selecting individuals systematically from a sampling frame.
A small trial run of a survey to check clarity and reduce errors.
Bias introduced when individuals can choose whether to participate in a sample.
A sample consisting of individuals who are conveniently available, often unrepresentative of the population.
Bias that occurs when a part of the population has less representation in the sample than in the population.
Bias introduced when a large fraction of those sampled fails to respond, leading to unrepresentative results.
Bias that occurs when anything in a survey design influences responses, such as the wording of questions.
